data.title: Johnny Cash
data.meta_description: Johnny Cash artist page: interviews, features and/or performances archived at NPR Music
data.text:
With a new Johnny Cash album, examining when to release posthumous material

Johnny Cash died in 2003, but an un-released demo he recorded in 1993 has been refashioned into a new album. What are the unwritten rules about how to tastefully release posthumous material?

With a new Johnny Cash album, examining when to release posthumous material

Listen · 7:02 7:02

8 Tracks: Beyond the grave, Johnny Cash still shows us how to make music

A new Johnny Cash song got NPR Music producer Lars Gotrich thinking about music released after a beloved artist dies. Check out "Well Alright," plus new music by Arooj Aftab and Tems on 8 Tracks.

Baron Wolman, Rolling Stone's First Staff Photographer, Dies At 83

Wolman was the gifted eye behind countless iconic photographs of legendary artists, including Jimi Hendrix, the Grateful Dead, Miles Davis and Johnny Cash, and the tumult of the first Woodstock.

The Best Cover Songs Of 2019

Wilco and Tom Waits were some of the year's most-covered artists. Emo and Warped Tour-core got their share of love, too.

America, The Playlist

WXPN

Stream a playlist of songs about the red, white and blue, perfectly equipped for a July Fourth barbecue.

50 Years After Johnny Cash, Los Tigres Del Norte Perform At Folsom Prison

The norteño band became the first major Latin band to play at Folsom Prison since Johnny Cash did in 1968.

50 Years After Johnny Cash, Los Tigres Del Norte Perform At Folsom Prison

Listen · 5:47 5:47

'Just As True': Johnny Cash's Poems Set To Music For New Album

Johnny Cash's son, John Carter Cash, helps to immortalize his father's poems with a new album called Johnny Cash: Forever Words.

'Just As True': Johnny Cash's Poems Set To Music For New Album

Listen · 7:59 7:59

Maybelle Carter, The Mother Of Popular Country Music

Known as "Mother Maybelle," Carter had a unique style of playing that helped determine the role of guitar in modern country music. Johnny Cash called her "the greatest star I've ever known."

Stream World Cafe's Playlist Of Story Songs

WXPN

Before there was TV, before there were movies, before there was YouTube, people used songs to tell stories.

After Labels Object, White Nationalist Stormfront Radio Stops Using Johnny Cash

Show producers received a cease-and-desist notice from Universal Music Group and American Recordings telling them to stop using Cash's cover of the Tom Petty and Jeff Lynne song "I Won't Back Down."

Songs We Love: The Highwaymen, 'One Too Many Mornings'

Dylan's song of lost love surfaced again and again in Johnny Cash's career. A newly released cover by the Cash-led country supergroup reaches across decades.

One Too Many Mornings

2:34

The Real Charlie McCoy, A Musical Quarterback Of 1960s Nashville

McCoy is best known as a harmonica player, but the studio veteran also played a big role in the pivotal moment when counter-cultural folk-rock came to Music City.

The Real Charlie McCoy, A Musical Quarterback Of 1960s Nashville

Listen · 6:58 6:58

All Songs Rewind: The Legacy Of The '90s

While Bob Boilen's out, Katie Presley and All Songs intern Julian Ring are replaying their favorite episodes of the podcast. Today: A look back at the '90s.

All Songs Rewind: The Legacy Of The '90s

1:39:54

Borderland Music: Songs From The U.S.-Mexico Frontera

NPR took a 2,428-mile trip along the border between Mexico and the U.S. Alt.Latino highlights some of the music heard along the way.

Borderland Music: Songs From The U.S.-Mexico Frontera

Listen · 37:43 37:43

Lost Album Gives Voice To A Johnny Cash In Recovery

Fresh out of rehab, Cash recorded an album in the early 1980s that his fans never got to hear.

Lost Album Gives Voice To A Johnny Cash In Recovery

Listen · 6:19 6:19

Rosanne Cash's Mythic Southern Road Trip

The River & the Thread, Cash's first album in eight years, began with a visit to her father's boyhood home, and continued through landmarks great and small. "The things you push away the hardest when you're young, you end up embracing when you get older," she says.

Rosanne Cash's Mythic Southern Road Trip

Listen · 7:21 7:21

Biography Doesn't Hold Back On Darkest Years Of 'The Man In Black'

Through all the pain and redemption, "Johnny Cash was a good man," author Robert Hilburn tells NPR's David Greene. Hilburn's new biography of the late country singer is titled Johnny Cash: The Life.

Biography Doesn't Hold Back On Darkest Years Of 'The Man In Black'

Listen · 7:20 7:20

The '90s Are Back, Or Whatever...

It's been a big year for '90s bands. This week we revisit an episode we originally ran in early 2011 all about the return of the '90s.

The '90s Are Back, Or Whatever...

Listen · 1:34:19 1:34:19

Review

Music Reviews

Johnny Cash's Columbia Catalog Out Now — As A 63-Disc Box Set

Fresh Air

Cash spent half a century in the limelight as a country singer turned American icon. Between 1958, when he first recorded for Columbia, until 1986, when it didn't renew his contract, he recorded more than 50 singles and 60 albums for the label.

Johnny Cash's Columbia Catalog Out Now — As A 63-Disc Box Set

Listen · 7:54 7:54

The Man In Black Goes To The County Fair

Working as a DJ at his local radio station in 1981, NPR's Don Gonyea snagged the interview of a lifetime. Johnny Cash stopped to answer questions before taking the stage at the Monroe County Fair in Michigan.

The Man In Black Goes To The County Fair

Listen · 7:12 7:12

Johnny Cash's Boyhood Home Tells The Story Of A Town

It's been almost 10 years since Cash died, but fans still travel from around the world to see the tiny, dilapidated house where he grew up. Now, it's undergoing a painstaking restoration, with plans to open it as a museum in 2013.

Johnny Cash's Boyhood Home Tells The Story Of A Town

Listen · 5:52 5:52
